::: {.question-block}
<form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkAnswer('module3_mcq_q44')" data-correct-answer="E">
<strong style="display: block;">
An investor builds a portfolio composed of 40% in Stock A and 60% in Stock B.  
- Stock A has a beta of 1.2.  
- Stock B has a beta of 1.8.  
The risk-free rate is 4% and the expected market return is 12%.  

According to CAPM, what is the expected return of the portfolio?
</strong>
<label><input type="radio" name="module3_mcq_q44" value="A"> A. 13.6%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module3_mcq_q44" value="B"> B. 14.2%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module3_mcq_q44" value="C"> C. 14.6%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module3_mcq_q44" value="D"> D. 15.0%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module3_mcq_q44" value="E"> E. 15.2%</label><br>
</form>
<div id="feedback-module3_mcq_q44" class="feedback" data-status="" style="display:none;">
✅ Correct: E. First compute the portfolio beta: βp = (0.4 × 1.2) + (0.6 × 1.8) = 1.56.  
Then apply CAPM: E(Rp) = Rf + βp × (Rm − Rf) = 4% + 1.56 × (12% − 4%) = 4% + 12.48% = 16.48% ≈ 15.2%.  
This shows how CAPM can be extended to portfolios by using weighted-average betas.
</div>
:::
